title: How to Clean a Travel Mug

steps.headline: Take off the lid and remove the rubber seal, if possible.
steps.description: First, untwist or pull on the lid on the mug to remove it. Then, if possible, pull on the rubber seal that lines the rim of the inside of the lid to slide it off. In some cases, the rubber seal is permanently attached to the mug’s lid. If this is the case, leave the lid as is.

steps.headline: Fill a bowl or the sink with warm water and dish soap.
steps.description: Turn on both the hot and cold water in the sink and let the water run for a few seconds, adjusting as needed until the water is warm but not hot. Then, plug the sink to fill it up, or fill up a large bowl. As the sink or bowl is filling up, add a squirt of dish soap, about 1 tablespoon (15 mL). Dish soap is gentle on travel mug materials and won’t deteriorate the rubber seal. Avoid using any chlorine-based cleaning products, as these can start to break down the rubber seal.

steps.headline: Soak the mug, lid, and rubber seal in the soapy water for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Once the sink or bowl is filled with soapy water, place the mug, lid, and rubber seal into the water. Make sure everything is submerged. Then, leave them to soak for 10 minutes. Giving them time to soak will help soften and loosen any residue or germs.

steps.headline: Scrub the mug parts with a bottle brush or clean toothbrush.
steps.description: First, dip the bottle brush or toothbrush into the soapy water to wet the bristles with the dish soap solution. Then, scrub all over the mug, lid, and rubber seal, making sure that you spend a bit of extra time scrubbing the crevices of the lid. This will remove residue, grim, or bacteria still stuck to any of the mug pieces. Make sure that the toothbrush or bottle brush is clean and sanitized before using it to scrub your travel mug.

steps.headline: Rinse all the mug, lid, and rubber seal with warm water.
steps.description: Once you’ve scrubbed all the mug parts with a brush, you can drain the sink or dump the soapy water from the bowl. Then, turn the sink water on warm and hold each of the parts under the running water. If your travel mug lid has a drink opening, open and close the top to make sure the you wash off all the soap.

steps.headline: Let the travel mug pieces air dry completely.
steps.description: Lay all the mug, lid, and rubber seal out on a clean paper towel. Leave them to air dry completely before putting the rubber seal back on the lid or placing the lid back on the mug. Replacing the lid before the mug is dry can trap moisture inside, which will allow bacteria to grow. If you want to use your mug right after cleaning it, you can dry it with a clean paper towel or microfiber cloth. Repeat this process after every use if possible, or at least every other use.

methods.name: Sanitizing with Baking Soda and Vinegar

steps.headline: Pour baking soda and distilled white vinegar into the mug.
steps.description: Remove the lid on your travel mug. Pour 1 teaspoon (5 grams) of baking soda into the mug first, then add ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of distilled white vinegar. Once you add the vinegar, the mixture will bubble up quite a bit. Wait for the bubbles to settle down for a few seconds before moving on to the next step.

steps.headline: Replace the lid on the travel mug.
steps.description: Once the bubbles have settled down, put the lid back on the mug. Make sure that it’s on tight so that the cleaning solution doesn’t spill out when you shake it. Make sure that the bubbles have settled down before replacing the lid. If it’s still bubbling up, the mixture could react and explode, leaving you with a mess.

steps.headline: Shake the mug several times to agitate the solution.
steps.description: Hold your hand over the top to make sure the lid stays on, then shake the mug about 5 to 10 times to get the baking soda and vinegar to bubble up again. Then, leave the mug alone for a few minutes to let the bubbles subside again. If your mug has a drinking spout and you want to ensure it gets sanitized, you can leave the spout open and cover it tightly with your thumb while you shake.

steps.headline: Rinse the mug with warm water.
steps.description: Once the bubbles have subsided, hold the mug under the sink faucet and turn the sink water on warm. Let the water fall into the cup with the solution so it’ll spill over and sanitize the sides of the mug. After it’s spilled over for a few seconds, dump the remaining solution out and rinse the rest of the solution out.

steps.headline: Wash the top of the lid with dish soap.
steps.description: Keeping the lid off the mug, squirt a dime-sized amount of dish soap onto the lid. Rub it around the top with your hands, then rinse the lid under the running water to remove the dish soap. If the mug lid has a drinking opening, rinse it in both the open and closed positions to make sure you wash the dish soap out of the crevices.

steps.headline: Let your travel mug air dry completely before using it.
steps.description: Once rinsed, place the mug and lid on a clean paper towel. Let the lid and mug air dry separately to avoid trapping any moisture inside, which could allow bacteria to start to grow. If possible, sanitize your travel mug after every use, or at least every other use.

methods.name: Keeping Travel Mugs Clean Between Hand Washes

steps.headline: Rinse your travel mug and lid with warm water after every use.
steps.description: If you don’t have any cleaning materials on hand, you can keep your travel mug relatively clean by rinsing it with warm water after each use. This will help prevent residue build-up and bacteria, which will make the mug generally easier to clean. Allowing the bacteria to fester will not only make your mug harder to clean, it can also make you sick. Therefore, it’s important to rinse your mug after every use.

steps.headline: Do a 15-minute water and vinegar soak to sanitize your mug quickly.
steps.description: If you don’t have time to scrub your travel mug or shake it with a baking soda and vinegar solution, you can sanitize it quickly in between hand washes by pouring 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of distilled white vinegar into the mug, then filling the rest with warm water. Let the mixture soak for 15 minutes, then rinse the mug with warm water and let it air dry.

steps.headline: Run the mug and lid through the dishwasher if it’s dishwasher safe.
steps.description: While you’ll be able to clean in the crevices of the lid and seal more effectively by hand washing, you can run your travel mug through the dishwasher between hand washes if it’s dishwasher safe. When washing it in the dishwasher, remove the lid and place both the lid and mug on the top rack of the dishwasher before adding detergent and running the cycle. Many travel mugs have a rubber seal made of polypropylene, which has a high tolerance for heat. Therefore, these can generally withstand the heat of the dishwasher. To be on the safe side, however, it’s best to place it on the top rack since the top gets less hot than the bottom. Even if your travel mug is dishwasher safe, the high heat will likely start to deteriorate the rubber seal over time. Therefore, only run your travel mug through the dishwasher about once per week, and stop putting it in the dishwasher if the mug starts to leak.
